body: I'd prefer to keep this PR open as a reminder.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1616/

Looks good to me.

The `for` loops may add to running time (why are the `parfor`s commented out?). At some point (when the builtin functions for conv2d, conv2d_backward_* are relatively stable), we should compare running times for the nn layer functions against other packages.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1617/

Thanks @krishnakalyan3, I shall merge. 
We can do a future PR is we've missed out something.
Thanks @niketanpansare, I shall merge.
@nakul02 thank you for the reviews.

Thanks, @prithvirajsen.  I agree that we should compare individual layers with other systems at some point in the near future.  As for the commented out `parfor` loops, I originally wanted to use them, but they first caused exceptions (fixed in master), and then they end up being slower.  The builtin `conv2d*` functions are internally multithreaded, but if they are run in the context of a local `parfor`, they are reduced to single-threaded ops, and the overall runtime slows down (~1.5x - 2x in my quick tests).  It's worth exploring more at some point, because for large numbers of channels >> the number of the examples, the `parfor` loops could possibly be faster.

well, it's hard to estimate that but I would guess it would be in the order of 2-3 person years to make it work for all backends and operations. Orthogonal to that, there is also the wish to support matrices of different value types (boolean, float, and double).

@deroneriksson - as discussed in the comments above, I absolutely agree but did not want to unnecessarily stall the PR for this; I'll take care of that in the context of testing this rewrite more thoroughly in the wild.
Great @mboehm7. I failed to see the comment WRT guava earlier. I see from the above comments that you noticed the guava dependency immediately. Good catch!
I made a PR #549 that removes the added Guava dependencies. Sorry for the trouble.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1619/

@dhutchis Thanks! Usually I would highly encourage the use of a library like Guava in this situation. We just have a constraint to try minimize the dependencies/memory needed for the in-memory scoring via JMLC.

Thanks @dhutchis for taking care of this. After debugging the failed test, it turned out that the hop comparator had an issue in one of the comparison cases, leading to "random" failures. I just delivered a fix for it but also temporarily disabled this rewrite because there are additional issues, where we would create invalid plans (e.g., with row and column vectors).

LGTM for this PR.

I was also thinking that we could force the [NNTest.java](https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/master/src/test/java/org/apache/sysml/test/integration/scripts/nn/NNTest.java) tests to run on a GPU if available, since those won't take as long, but they will fail for that same reason.
Ping @asurve - let me know when you want me to merge this.

"we should think about separating JVM and GPU memory requirements and budgets." - I very much agree. We should also put a plan in place to decouple other backends. It makes the adding and removing/disabling of backends straight-forward.

https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1633/

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1634/

sure, but let's be more specific here: these memory estimates reflect singlenode operations; any distributed backends anyway have very different semantics and memory estimates and budgets. The interesting thing about GPUs is that the memory estimates will be very similar (once we have full support for dense/sparse) but the budget is different.

Great, can you also post the computation "plan" for the problematic function both  with and without the `if (1==1) {}` hack?  The "plan" is basically the graph of operations within the engine, and we have a mechanism of printing out that graph.  There are a few different levels, such as HOPS (high level operations in the optimizer, without any notion of Spark, drivers, Java, etc.), RUNTIME (the actual ops being run on either Spark, plain Java, etc.), etc.  From the API, there is a `setExplain` function that can turn plan explanations on/off, and a `setExplainLevel` to change the type of plans exposed.

All together, the error message and the plans will help to debug the actual issue, which seems to be an internal issue that is causing a matrix size to be set to an incorrect value.
That is correct, the memory budgets for GPU are different now because of the incomplete support for dense/sparse matrices.

ok thanks for catching this @feihugis - here is what happened: (1) after removing the (1==1){}, the function transpose_NCHW_to_CNHW got inlined, and (2) during recompilation we applied an invalid rewrite  (fuseAxpyBinaryOperationChain) for outer(seq(1,C), C*t(seq(0,N-1)), "+"). The invalid rewrite was also applied with (1==1){}, but (due to another chain of events) did not update the size output sizes and hence did not crash. I'll push a fix later tonight.

This is great work @krishnakalyan3!

For the purpose of Phase 1 of GSoC, this code is merge-able as it is.

But, either in this PR or as part of your next phase, I'd like you to document the overall design and assumptions in the main entry file. This could include things like example runs, what a `family` is, how to add new algorithm and anything else you think appropriate.
You should also explain why there is json file being generated for each job being run (as in which library you are using so that this needs to happen). what was the design choice for this library?

Towards the end, we'd also like to add a User Guide with lots of examples.

In this PR thread, or in your comment where you have the list of tasks completed, could you please indicate which families, algorithms, data sizes, shapes that you have tested for. Also what is the machine that you tested on (its configuration), any spark settings (how many executors, memory sizes of driver, executor), any single node settings (JVM memory), etc.

Ping @mboehm7 - I am going to leave the proposed change as is for the case of when "subsequent (data-dependent) operation cannot be compiled to GPU".
Additionally, the situation when driver mem budget is less than GPU mem budget is taken care of.
Could you please review this PR (I think its ready).
LGTM. Thank you @opengjenkins

BTW, for future reference, typically I would name the PR something like "[MINOR] Fix typo in ALS notebook" or something similar to that. The "[MINOR]" indicates that this is a small change, typically without an accompanying JIRA, and the "ALS" is nice since it allows someone looking at the git logs to determine what notebook was modified.

Thank you for the contribution!
